analytic.title: Marine Pollution Bulletin

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

textClass.keywords: Brooding coral Octocoral Blue coral Philippines Planulation

abstract.p: Recurrent thermal stress events and intensified precipitation alter the ocean environment resulting in the decline of coral populations. However, the influence of these changes on larval survival and settlement is not well understood. We examined the effect of salinity (15, 20, 25, 30, 35, and 40 ppt) and temperature (27°C, 30°C, and 33°C) on settlement and survival of larvae of the octocoral, Heliopora coerulea. Larvae settled successfully at salinities from 25 to 30 ppt. On the other hand, larval survival and settlement decreased with increasing temperature. A combination of 25-35 ppt and 27-30°C resulted in highest survival and settlement. These results indicate that early life stages of H. coerulea are negatively impacted by thermal stress but may be able to survive at reduced salinity. The wider tolerance range of H. coerulea larvae compared to most scleractinian larvae may thus contribute to the success of this coral on disturbed reef ecosystems.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Corals have a biphasic life cycle that includes benthic and pelagic stages. As such, the dynamics and persistence of coral populations are dependent on the success of corals during their early life history, particularly during fertilization, settlement, and metamorphosis (Richmond et al., 2018). During these early life stages, corals experience high mortality because of predation, competition, and environmental perturbations (Ritson-Williams et al., 2009;Vermeij and Sandin, 2008). Yet, how much environmental variability can be tolerated by corals during the pelagobenthic transition is not well understood, especially for less-studied groups like the octocorals.

Corals typically thrive in an environment where they experience average maximum temperatures of~30°C with seasonal changes in water temperature ranging from~8 to 10°C (Kleypas et al., 1999) and salinity ranging from 25 to 45 ppt (Ferrier-Pages et al., 1999;Manzello and Lirman, 2003). Resilience to environmental perturbations is influenced by a multitude of factors, including morphology, associated symbionts, gene expression, hydrographics, and history of exposure (McClanahan et al., 2012). However, anthropogenic activities, such as mariculture and coastal development, along with climate change-associated disturbances, such as intensified precipitation and thermal stress, can alter marine environmental conditions to levels detrimental to coral reproduction and survival. In adult corals, reduced salinity has been shown to cause osmotic stress while elevated temperature impacts coral symbiosis (Chavanich et al., 2012;Kuanui et al., 2015). Thus, the influence of these stressors on coral larvae, individually or in combination, needs to be examined further, especially for octocorals.

The octocoral, Heliopora coerulea, although uncommon within its geographic range, can dominate the community on certain reefs (Takino et al., 2010;Vergara et al., 2010). H. coerulea is a gonochoric brooding coral (Babcock, 1990). The coral releases azooxanthellate planula larvae that tend to settle a few hours after hatching (Babcock, 1990;Harii and Kayanne, 2003). This behavior contributes to a narrow dispersal range (< 5 km), dominance in specific reef sites, and low genotypic diversity within some populations (Yasuda N et al., 2014). This may be compounded by the ability of the coral to inhibit the settlement of heterospecific larvae in its vicinity (Atrigenio et al., 2017). Furthermore, H. coerulea is believed to have a higher thermal optimum and a lower bleaching susceptibility compared to scleractinian corals (Hajime et al., 2002;Zann and Bolton, 1985).

In the Bolinao-Anda Reef Complex in northwestern Philippines, H. coerulea comprised about 39% of all coral species across 44 sites (2-9 m depth) surveyed in 2009 and was the dominant species at 86% of the sites (Vergara et al., 2010). The Bolinao reef system is subject to a multitude of environmental stressors, including frequent thermal stress events accompanied by mass coral bleaching, as observed in 1998, 2010, and 2016 (Arceo et al., 2001;Peñaflor et al., 2009), as well as reduced salinity due to submarine groundwater discharge and frequent and intense rainfall (Cardenas et al., 2010;Villafuerte II et al., 2015).

https://doi.org/10.1016/j.marpolbul.2019.110703 Received 2 April 2019; Received in revised form 6 September 2019; Accepted 30 October 2019 However, it is not yet known whether these factors influence the distribution and abundance of H. coerulea in the region.

This study aimed to investigate the effects of reduced salinity and increased temperature on the survival and settlement of H. coerulea larvae. We tested the tolerance of H. coerulea larvae to a wide range of salinities, i.e., 15, 20, 25, 30, 35, and 40 ppt, and temperatures, i.e., 27, 30, and 33°C. Understanding how H. coerulea larvae respond to changes in environmental conditions may provide insights into the success of this species in certain reef areas.

div.head: Coral collection and maintenance
div.p: Six (6) reproductively mature colonies of H. coerulea were collected from Cangaluyan reef (16°22′79.2″, 120°00′17.3″) in the Bolinao-Anda reef complex, northwestern Philippines. Based on regular monitoring by the Bolinao Marine Laboratory, the average annual temperature at the site from 2016 to 2018 was 29.31 ± 1.75°C. During the coldest months of the year (December to February), average temperature ranged from 26 to 27°C with minima of 23-24°C. During the warmest months (May to July), average temperature ranged from 30 to 31°C with maxima of 33-34°C. Average salinity in the area ranged from 31 to 34 ppt. However, during the monsoon season or after intense precipitation events, seawater salinities as low as 26-30 ppt have been recorded (Sayco et al., 2019). Coral colonies (approximately 35 cm in diameter) were brought to the outdoor hatchery of the Bolinao Marine Laboratory (BML) of the Marine Science Institute, University of the Philippines. Colonies were placed in buckets with flowing seawater and aeration. Seawater flow was turned off before sunset. The following morning released larvae were collected by filtration through a 120 μm nylon mesh (Villanueva et al., 2008). Larvae released on the same day by different colonies were pooled and placed in a container at a stocking density of around 1 individual per 2 ml. Larvae were randomly collected from this pool for the different experiments.

div.head: Larval settlement
div.p: To assess the viability of larvae, settlement competency was determined. 10 larvae collected at 0, 1, 2, and 3 days post hatching (dph) were placed into 6 cm petri dishes containing a 0.5 sq. cm. piece of crustose coralline algae (CCA) in 10 ml UV-filtered seawater at normal salinity of 35 ppt (n = 3 replicate setups per age of larvae). Plates were incubated at ambient room temperature (28 ± 1°C). The number of larvae that settled on the CCA chip were enumerated after 6 h. Only larvae that had ceased swimming, assumed a rounded morphology, and had attached to the CCA substrate were considered settled.

div.head: Salinity effects
div.p: Settlement experiments were conducted in clear open plastic containers containing~500 ml UV-filtered seawater maintained at the desired salinity level. In order to test larval tolerance to a broad range of salinities, treatment conditions included 15, 20, 25, 30, 35, and 40 ppt. Salinity was adjusted by diluting natural seawater with distilled water or by addition of artificial sea salt. Salinity levels were verified using a handheld refractometer (Atago). Fiber cement tiles that had been preconditioned for 3 weeks in flowing ambient seawater (31-33 ppt) were placed into each container. 100 larvae (at 0 dph) were directly introduced from ambient seawater into each setup (n = 5 replicates per salinity). Temperature was not specifically controlled in this experiment and setups were maintained at ambient room temperature (28 ± 1°C) with a 12:12 light:dark cycle. The number of settled larvae on each tile was enumerated by checking all sides of the tiles every day until day 9. Seawater in each setup was replaced every 2 days.

div.head: Temperature effects
div.p: Larvae (at 0 dph) were directly transferred from ambient seawater into glass vials containing 20 ml of UV filtered seawater (35 ppt) at densities of 2, 4, or 6 larvae per vial. Salinity in the setups was maintained at 35 ppt to represent average ocean salinity. Vials were capped and submerged into tanks containing seawater maintained at ± 1°C, 30 ± 1°C, and 33 ± 1°C (n = 10 vials per density per temperature). Setups were illuminated with a 12:12 light:dark cycle. After 3 days, a CCA chip was introduced into 5 vials at each density and temperature combination. The number of live and settled larvae in each vial was monitored for up to 9 days. Seawater in the vials was not replaced throughout the duration of the experiment.

div.head: Combined effects
div.p: 10 larvae (at 0 dph) were placed into glass vials containing 20 ml of UV filtered seawater at salinities of 15, 25, and 35 ppt. Vials were submerged into tanks containing seawater maintained at 27 ± 1°C, ± 1°C, and 33 ± 1°C (n = 6 vials per salinity per temperature). Setups were illuminated with a 12:12 light:dark cycle. After 3 days, a 0.5 sq. cm. CCA chip was introduced into 3 vials at each salinity and temperature combination. The number of live and settled larvae in each vial was monitored for up to 9 days. Seawater in the vials was not replaced throughout the duration of the experiment.

div.head: Data analyses
div.p: General Linear Models (GLM) were used to examine the differences in survival and settlement of coral larvae exposed to the different temperature and salinity treatments across days. Significant GLM results were further tested using a post-hoc Tukey's HSD test to compare pairwise differences in survival and settlement between temperature treatments or between salinity treatments. All tests were conducted using the program Statistica.

div.head: Results
div.p: 3.1. Larval settlement H. coerulea larvae were able to settle on crustose coralline algae less than 24 h after release from the parent colony. Although there appeared to be an increase in % settlement on CCA with increasing age of larvae ( Fig. 1), the differences were not statistically supported (GLM: F = 1.30, p = 0.32; Table 1a).

div.head: Salinity effects
div.p: H. coerulea larvae were allowed to settle on conditioned fiber cement tiles at salinities of 15, 20, 25, 30, 35, and 40 ppt. Larvae introduced into low salinity seawater (15-20 ppt) swelled up and sank to the bottom whereas larvae introduced into high salinity seawater (40 ppt) floated to the top and appeared thin and thread-like (Fig. 2). In contrast, larvae at 25-35 ppt shifted between a spherical and ovate shape while actively exploring surfaces. Larval settlement was observed starting at 2 days after introduction to the tiles only for setups at 25, 30, and 35 ppt (Fig. 2). Salinity significantly affected the settlement of H. coerulea larvae (GLM: F = 46.14, p < 0.0001; Table 1a). The highest average settlement rate was 10.13 ± 0.03% at 30 ppt. This was followed by 6.67 ± 0.65% at 35 ppt, 5.78 ± 0.47% at 25 ppt. Less than 1% of larvae settled at 15, 20, and 40 ppt.

div.head: Temperature effects
div.p: Larval survival was lowest at a seawater temperature of 33°C (Tukey's post hoc test: p < 0.05). The average survival of H. coerulea larvae was 99.03 ± 0.39% at 27°C, 93.52 ± 0.99% at 30°C, and 90.37 ± 1.49% at 33°C. Seeding density of the larvae also had an effect on survival over time (GLM, density*time interaction: F = 2.22, p = 0.011; Table 1b). H. coerulea larvae had lowest survival (89.11 ± 1.21%) at high density (0.3 larvae per ml) compared to 99.52 ± 0.48% and 94.28 ± 1.23% survival at low (0.1 larvae per ml) or moderate (0.2 larvae per ml) densities, respectively (Fig. 3A). Temperature and density showed significant interaction effects. Larval survival did not vary between temperatures at the lowest density. However, at high larval density, survival decreased significantly with increasing temperature.

Temperature had a significant effect on the settlement of H. coerulea larvae (GLM, temperature: F = 3.30, p=.041; Table 1b) ( Fig. 3B). Settlement was higher at 27°C compared to 30°C and 33°C (Tukey's post hoc test: p < 0.05). Average settlement was 19.29 ± 4.02% at 27°C, 17.07 ± 3.52% at 30°C, and 7.62 ± 2.31% at 33°C. Density had no significant effect on settlement.

div.head: Combined effects
div.p: Temperature had a greater effect on survival than salinity, as shown by the differences in F values between temperature and salinity (GLM, temperature: F = 73.50, p < 0.001; salinity: F = 14.46, p < 0.001, Table 1c). Although, there was a significant interaction between temperature and salinity (GLM, F = 9.48, p < 0.001). Average percent survival was significantly lower at 15 ppt (86.11 ± 2.90%) compared to 25 ppt (94.44 ± 1.49%) and 35 ppt (95.00 ± 1.49%). Average survival was significantly lower at 33°C (78.89 ± 2.92%) compared to 27°C (98.33 ± 0.51%) and 30°C (98.33 ± 0.51%) (Fig. 4A). The combination of 15 ppt and 33°C resulted in a drastic reduction of survival to 63.89 ± 5.72% (Tukey's post hoc test: p < 0.05).

Temperature had a significant effect on settlement (GLM: F = 6.62, p = 0.003, Table 1c). Average settlement at 33°C was only 1.48 ± 1.48%, while settlement was 19.26 ± 3.85% at 27°C and 14.07 ± 4.18% at 30°C (Fig. 4B). Settlement of larvae did not vary significantly between salinities, with 6.67 ± 2.72% settlement at ppt, 14.81 ± 4.63% at 25 ppt, and 13.33 ± 3.25% at 35 ppt. Settlement rates of 23.33 ± 8.97% and 23.33 ± 4.41% were observed for larvae at 27°C in combination with 25 ppt and 35 ppt, while 21.11 ± 9.34% and 12.22 ± 6.41% settlement were observed for larvae at 30°C in combination with 25 ppt and 35 ppt, respectively. There was no significant interaction effect between temperature and salinity on settlement.

div.head: Discussion
div.p: In this study, we revealed the effects of temperature and salinity stresses on the survival and settlement of H. coerulea larvae. The larvae tolerated salinities between 25 and 35 ppt and were negatively impacted by salinities below or above this range. Maximum survival and settlement were observed at a salinity of 30 ppt, which approximates the salinity levels at the site during rainy season (Sayco et al., 2019).

div.head: Table 1
div.p: Summary results of the GLM tests, showing the significant differences in % survival and % settlement of Heliopora coerulea larvae: a) between age, and salinity and time; b) between temperature, density, and time; and c) between temperature, salinity, and time. Reduced salinity may become typical of this region in the future, given that extreme rainfall events that cause drastic reduction in seawater salinity are reported to occur with much greater frequency, particularly in northwestern Philippines, with rainfall events recorded even during the months of April and May when H. coerulea are planulating (Villafuerte II et al., 2015). In addition, substantial submarine groundwater discharge may contribute freshwater input locally near the reef site (Cardenas et al., 2010).

div.head: Larval settlement
div.p: Like larvae from brooding scleractinians, the larvae of H. coerulea were able to settle on crustose coralline algae after less than 24 h of release from the brood chambers of the parent colony and were still competent to settle after 3 days of hatching (Harii and Kayanne, 2003). Compared to larvae of Acropora sp. and Pocillopora sp., H. coerulea larvae have lower lipid content consisting mostly of rapidly metabolized triacylglycerols, which support a shorter dispersal period and Fig. 2. Influence of salinity on H. coerulea larvae. Percent settlement (average ± standard error of the means) of larvae exposed to different levels of salinity for 9 days. Representative images of larvae (white arrowheads) at different salinities are shown on the right (15 ppt, yellow; 20 ppt, orange; 25 ppt, purple; 30 ppt, green; 35 ppt, blue; 40 ppt, red). (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the Web version of this article.) Fig. 3. Influence of temperature on settlement and survival of H. coerulea larvae. (A) Percent survival (average ± standard error of the means) and (B) percent settlement of larvae seeded at different densities (0.1, 0.2, and 0.3 larvae per ml) and exposed to different levels of temperature (27, 30, and 33°C). immediate settlement (Harii et al., 2007).

div.head: Salinity effects
div.p: Impacts of reduced salinity, including fertilization success and larval survival, have been studied in many coral taxa, particularly of broadcast spawning corals (Humphrey et al., 2008;Scott et al., 2013). Yet, studies on the influence of reduced salinity on the larvae of brooding octocorals are limited. While corals are thought to be stenohaline osmoconformers with a limited tolerance for salinity fluctuations (Ferrier-Pages et al., 1999;Hoegh-Guldberg and Smith, 1989;True, 2012), susceptibility to salinity stress can vary across genera and is linked to the adaptation of corals to conditions typically encountered in their environment (Berkelmans et al., 2012;Hedouin et al., 2015). However, species-specific differences in salinity tolerance have also been observed even for corals that experience similar environmental fluctuations. For example, Acropora hyacinthus, Favites abdita, Platygyra daedalea, and P. sinensis from Thailand exhibit reduced settlement at 28-32 ppt (True, 2012) whereas a salinity of 28-36 ppt had no effect on Orbicella faceolata from the Florida Keys (Vermeij et al., 2006). Larvae of Acropora cytherea and A. pulchra from French Polynesia also exhibited significant reduction in survival at 26 ppt (Hedouin et al., 2015). Fertilization and survival of P. daedalea and A. millepora from the Great Barrier Reef were similarly reduced at salinities of 25.8 and 33.1 ppt, with even greater reduction in survival at 18.4 ppt (Scott et al., 2013). These studies demonstrate that lowered salinity during spawning may be detrimental to the reproductive success and recruitment of these corals.

In contrast, H. coerulea larvae were able to survive and settle at salinities ranging from 20 to 35 ppt, indicating that the larvae have the ability to osmoregulate over a broad range of salinities. Marine invertebrates synthesize and degrade compatible organic osmolytes such as glycerol, a polyol, and free amino acids (FAAs) to alter intracellular osmolarity and maintain homeostasis (Mayfield and Gates, 2007). It is possible that H. coerulea larvae produce similar osmolytes to maintain normal cellular functions under salinity stress. However, it is important to note that, since the settlement substrates used in the experiment were conditioned at a salinity range of 31-33 ppt, they may be covered in microbial biofilm that is adapted to reduced salinity conditions. As the biofilm community plays a key role in the induction of coral larval metamorphosis (Webster et al., 2004), future studies are needed to examine how biofilm formation is affected by variations in seawater salinity and whether this would have a subsequent influence on the settlement of coral larvae.

Salinity affected the buoyancy of H. coerulea larvae. Below 25 ppt, larvae were negatively buoyant and displayed signs of hypoosmotic stress. On the other hand, larvae in salinity of 40 ppt experienced hyperosmotic stress and remained positively buoyant. These observations suggest that salinity conditions ranging from 25 to 35 ppt may support effective settlement as it allows the larvae to control buoyancy within the water column.

div.head: Temperature effects
div.p: Elevated temperature has been shown to have varied effects on larvae of different species of corals. H. coerulea larvae exhibited high survival at 27°C and 30°C, which is within the typical temperature range recorded at the reef where parental colonies were collected. In addition, although there was reduced survival and settlement at 33°C, some of the H. coerulea larvae were able to survive 9 days of sustained exposure to this temperature. This is in stark contrast to Pocillopora damicornis coral larvae, which exhibited deleterious effects after only 5 days at 30.5°C (Cumbo et al., 2013).

The relative tolerance of H. coerulea larvae to elevated temperature may be partly due to their larger size and azooxanthellate nature. The presence of photosynthetic symbionts in larvae may produce reactive oxygen species (ROS) that can lead to high levels of lipid peroxidation and DNA damage (Nesa et al., 2012;Yakovleva et al., 2009). On the other hand, the survival of P. damicornis larvae at warmer temperatures has been attributed to the ability of symbionts present in the larval tissues to replenish lipid stores (Haryanti et al., 2015). However, while it is known that H. coerulea associates with thermotolerant symbiont types (Guzman et al., 2018), there is a need to examine whether these symbionts would contribute to the resilience of the coral at later stages Fig. 4. Influence of temperature and salinity on settlement and survival of H. coerulea larvae. (A) Percent survival (average ± standard error of the means) and (B) percent settlement of larvae exposed to different levels of temperature (27, 30, and 33°C) and salinity (15, 25, and 35 ppt). Larval density was 0.5 larvae per ml.

of its life cycle. Larval size is another factor that might influence temperature tolerance. The larger larvae of Fungia fungites have been found to tolerate temperatures of up to 34°C, whereas the smaller larvae of Lithophyllon repanda do not survive above 31°C (Baria et al., 2015). Differences in thermal sensitivity may also be attributed to differences in life history, with larvae of brooders, such as F. fungites and P. damicornis, exhibiting higher temperature tolerance than larvae of broadcast spawning corals (Cumbo et al., 2013;Haryanti et al., 2015;Randall and Szmant, 2009). Moreover, latitudinal differences in thermal tolerance among corals may be related to the history of exposure of the parental colonies to thermal stress regimes (Hoeksema and Matthews, 2011;Loya et al., 2001;Thompson and Woesik, 2009). For instance, settlement and post-settlement survival of P. acuta from Hong Kong were not affected by elevated temperature, likely because of the large annual range of temperature experienced in this locality (Chui and Ang, 2017). Studies have also shown that elevated temperature of 29°C reduced larval swimming and facilitated settlement of Stylophora pistillata from southern Taiwan (Putnam et al., 2008).

It should be noted that increased larval mortality was observed at high density and high temperature conditions. This may be due to faster metabolic rate coupled with rapid utilization of oxygen by the larvae. In the experimental vials, where oxygen is limiting due to lack of water exchange, the effect of oxygen depletion may be particularly critical at high larval density and elevated temperature. Moreover, deterioration of water quality in the treatments with high temperature and high larval density may have contributed to higher mortality rates.

div.head: Combined effects
div.p: In the face of disturbances induced by global climate change, coral populations are exposed to multiple stressors including elevated temperature and reduced salinity (Descombes et al., 2015;Hoegh-Guldberg et al., 2007). In the current study, we observed that, while increasing temperature by~3°C above the yearly average reduced the survival of coral larvae to 25%, this effect was not intensified when coupled with exposure to reduced salinity. Thus, elevated temperature had a greater impact on larval survival and settlement than reduced salinity. Simultaneous exposure to the two stressors had no detectable additive effect on H. coerulea larvae. Similar observations have been reported in other species of adult corals exposed to both stressors (Buddemeier and Fautin, 1993;Chavanich et al., 2012;Reynaud et al., 2004). These contrast with observations in P. acuta from Hong Kong, which exhibited enhanced settlement under a combination of elevated temperature and reduced salinity of 22 and 26 ppt (Chui and Ang, 2017). The variability in response among corals may be attributed to historical exposure to different stressors that have allowed the corals to acclimatize and adapt to local conditions (Berkelmans et al., 2012;Hedouin et al., 2015).

Reports suggest that octocorals are more tolerant to ocean warming than scleractinian corals (Kayanne et al., 2002;Shaish et al., 2010). These differences may be reflected by the genetic complement of each species. In the octocoral, Corallium rubrum, genetic markers that point to potential adaptations for survival in highly variable environments were observed by comparing individuals living in shallow depths and those from deeper and more stable environments (Pratlong et al., 2015). Moreover, sequencing of the adult H. coerulea transcriptome revealed enrichment of transcripts encoding heat shock proteins and antioxidant enzymes that may be important for maintenance of cellular homeostasis under stress conditions (Guzman et al., 2018). This suggests that octocorals possess genetic adaptations that contribute to their ability to tolerate warmer seawater temperatures. Whether these and other stress response genes are expressed in the coral larvae remains to be determined.

div.head: Summary
div.p: The larvae of H. coerulea exhibit tolerance to a wide range of salinity and warmer seawater temperatures. These characteristics would likely benefit this species in future climate change scenarios where extreme rainfall and thermal stress events are predicted to occur more frequently. At sites where environmental conditions inhibit the early life processes of more vulnerable scleractinian coral species, the robust nature of H. coerulea larvae may contribute to its recruitment success, persistence, and eventual dominance on many Indo-Pacific coral reefs in the future.

figure.head: Fig. 1 .
figure.figDesc: Settlement competence of H. coerulea larvae. Percent settlement (average ± standard error of the means) of larvae at different days posthatching.

div.head: Acknowledgements
div.p: The authors thank Sherry Lyn Sayco and the staff of the Bolinao Marine Laboratory, particularly Renato Adolfo and Romer Albino, for assistance with the experiments. This study was funded in part by a grant from the Philippine Council for Agriculture, Aquatic, and Natural Resources Research and Development of the Department of Science and Technology to PCC and CC (QMSR-MRRD-MEC-295-1449). CC was also supported by the University of the Philippines System Emerging Interdisciplinary Research Grant (OVPAA-EIDR-C04-005).
